2.1 Preparing a Computer Investigation
• Role as a computer forensics professional is to gather
evidence
• From suspect’s computer and determine whether the
suspect committed a crime or violated a company policy
• If crime is found, begin to prepare a case, which is a
collection of evidence you can offer in court or at a
corporate inquiry.
• Investigating the suspect’s computer and then preserving
the evidence on a different computer.
2.1 Preparing a Computer Investigation
• Approaching each case methodically, you can evaluate the
evidence thoroughly
• Document the chain of evidence, or chain of custody
• Two examples:
– Computer Crime
– Company policy violation
2.1 Preparing a Computer Investigation
Overview of a Computer Crime:
• Computers can contain information that helps law
enforcement officers
• Determine the chain of events leading to a crime or
information providing evidence.
• Example of a case in which computers were involved in a
crime:
• Police raided a suspected drug dealer’s home and found a
computer, several floppy disks and USB drives.
• a personal digital assistant (PDA), and a cell phone in a
bedroom
2.1 Preparing a Computer Investigation
Overview of a Computer Crime:
Crime Scene
2.1 Preparing a Computer Investigation
Overview of a Computer Crime:
• The computer was “bagged and tagged”.
• It was placed in evidence bags along with the storage media
• Labeled with tags as part of the search and seizure.
• Lead detective on the case wants you to examine the
computer to find and organize data that could be evidence
of a crime.
• Acquisitions officer gives you documentation of items
• Acquisitions officer also notes that the computer is a
Windows XP
2.1 Preparing a Computer Investigation
Overview of a Computer Crime:
• The machine was running when it was discovered.
• Acquisitions officer photographs all open windows.
• Before shutting down the computer, a live acquisition
should be done to capture RAM, too.
• U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) has a document you can
download that reviews proper acquisition of electronic
evidence, including the search and seizure of computers
2.1 Preparing a Computer Investigation
Overview of a Computer Crime:
• In your preliminary assessment assume that the hard
disk and storage media include
• Intact files, such as e-mail messages, deleted files, and
hidden files.
• The files on the disks you received are probably
password protected.
• Acquire password-cracking software or find an expert
who can help you decrypt a file.
2.1 Preparing a Computer Investigation
Overview of a Company Policy Violation:
• Employees surfing the Internet, sending personal e-mail.
• Using company computers for personal tasks during work
hours can waste company time.
• Lost time can cost companies millions of dollars.
• Computer forensics specialists are often used to investigate
policy violations.
Ex: Employees absent and non reporting
2.2 Taking a Systematic Approach
You can apply standard systems analysis steps:
1. Make an initial assessment about the type of case you’re
investigating
2. Determine a preliminary design or approach to the case
3. Create a detailed checklist
4. Determine the resources you need
5. Obtain and copy an evidence drive
6. Identify the risks
2.2 Taking a Systematic Approach
7. Mitigate or minimize the risks
8. Test the design
9. Analyze and recover the digital evidence
10. Investigate the data you recover
11. Complete the case report
12. Critique the case
2.2 Taking a Systematic Approach
Assessing the Case
You can begin assessing this case as follows:
i. Situation
ii. Nature of the case
iii. Specifics of the case
iv. Type of evidence
v. Operating system
vi. Known disk format
vii. Location of evidence
2.2 Taking a Systematic Approach
Planning Your Investigation
To investigate the Domain Name case, you should perform the
following general steps:
1. Acquire the USB drive from Employee’s manager.
2. Complete an evidence form and establish a chain of custody.
3. Transport the evidence to your computer forensics lab.
4. Place the evidence in an approved secure container.
5. Prepare your forensic workstation.
2.2 Taking a Systematic Approach
Planning Your Investigation
6. Retrieve the evidence from the secure container.
7. Make a forensic copy of the evidence drive (in this case, the
USB drive).
8. Return the evidence drive to the secure container.
9. Process the copied evidence drive with your computer
forensics tools.
2.2 Taking a Systematic Approach
Planning Your Investigation
2.2 Taking a Systematic Approach
Securing Your Evidence
• If the evidence for a case includes an entire computer system,
• And associated storage media, such as floppy disks, Zip and Jaz
cartridges, 4 mm DDS digital audio tape (DAT), and USB drivesBe flexible.
• Some evidence is small enough to fit into an evidence bag.
• When gathering products to secure your computer evidence,
make sure they are safe and effective to use on computer
components.
• Make sure you use antistatic bags when collecting computer
evidence.
2.3 Procedures for Corporate High-Tech
Investigations
Employee Termination Cases
• Incidents that create a hostile work environment, such as
– viewing pornography in the workplace
– sending inappropriate e-mail messages
• Consulting with your organization’s general counsel and
Human Resources Department is recommended.
2.3 Procedures for Corporate High-Tech
Investigations
Internet Abuse Investigations
• To conduct an investigation involving Internet abuse, you need
the following:
i. The organization’s Internet proxy server logs
ii. Suspect computer’s IP address obtained from your
organization’s network administrator
iii. Suspect computer’s disk drive
iv. Your preferred computer forensics analysis tool
2.3 Procedures for Corporate High-Tech
Investigations
E-mail Abuse Investigations
 An electronic copy of the offending e-mail that contains
message header data;
 If available, e-mail server log records
 For e-mail systems that store users’ messages on a central
server, access to the server
 For e-mail systems that store users’ messages on a computer
as an Outlook .pst or .ost file
 Your preferred computer forensics analysis tool, such as
Forensic Toolkit or ProDiscover
2.3 Procedures for Corporate High-Tech
Investigations
Media Leak Investigations
• In the corporate environment, controlling sensitive data can
be difficult.
• To embarrass management to a rival conducting a power
struggle between other internal organizations.
• Premature release of information about new products causing
Business Loss.
2.3 Procedures for Corporate High-Tech
Investigations
Consider the following guidelines for media leak investigations:
 Examine e-mail, both the organization’s e-mail servers and
private e-mail accounts
 Examine Internet message boards, and search the Internet for
any information about the company or product.
 Examine proxy server logs to check for log activities
 Examine known suspects’ workstations
 Examine all company phone records
2.4 Understanding Data Recovery
Workstations and Software
• For investigation and analysis, have a specially configured PC
known as a forensic workstation.
• Microsoft Windows operating system can be used.
• Windows products are being developed that make performing
disk forensics easier.
• Windows has limitations in performing disk forensics, you
need skills in acquiring data with MS-DOS and Linux.
2.4 Understanding Data Recovery
Workstations and Software
Setting Up Your Workstation for Computer Forensics
a) A workstation running Windows OS(Windows 10)
b) A write-blocker device
c) Computer forensics acquisition tool
d) Computer forensics analysis tool
e) A target drive to receive the source or suspect disk data
f) Spare PATA or SATA ports
g) USB ports
2.5 Conducting an Investigation
You need the following items:
• Original storage media
• Evidence custody form
• Evidence container for the storage media (evidence bag)
• Bit-stream imaging tool
• Forensic workstation to copy and examine the evidence
• Secure evidence locker, cabinet, or safe
2.5 Conducting an Investigation
Gathering the Evidence
1. Pick up the storage media from IT Manager
2. Fill out the evidence form, have him sign it, then sign it
yourself.
3. Store the storage media in an evidence bag
4. Carry the evidence to a secure container, such as a locker,
cabinet, or safe.
5. Complete the evidence custody form.
6. Secure the evidence by locking the container.
2.5 Conducting an Investigation
Understanding Bit-stream Copies
• A bit-stream copy is a bit-by-bit copy (also known as a sector
copy) of the original drive or storage medium and is an exact
duplicate.
• A bit-stream image is the file containing the bit-stream copy of
all data on a disk.
• Referred as an “image,” “image save,” or “image file.”
• Some manufacturers also refer to it as a forensic copy.
2.5 Conducting an Investigation
Understanding Bit-stream Copies
2.5 Conducting an Investigation
Acquiring an Image of Evidence Media
• After you retrieve and secure the evidence, you’re ready to
copy the evidence media and analyze the data.
• The first rule of computer forensics is to preserve the original
evidence.
• Analysis only on a copy of the data.
2.5 Conducting an Investigation
Analyzing your digital evidence
• Analyze your Digital evidence using tools like
– ProDiscover
– FTK Imager
– Helix
2.6 Completing the case
You need to find the answers to the following questions to write
the final report:
• How did Employee’s manager acquire the disk?
• Did Employee perform the work on a laptop, which is his own
property?
• At what times of the day was Employee using the non-workrelated files?
• How did you retrieve that information?
• Which company policies apply?
• Are there any other items that need to be considered?
2.6 Completing the case
Critiquing the Case
• How could you improve your performance in the case?
• Did you expect the results you found? Did the case develop in
ways you did not expect?
• Was the documentation as thorough as it could have been?
• What feedback has been received from the requesting source?
• Did you discover any new problems? If so, what are they?
• Did you use new techniques during the case or during
research?
End of Chapter-2

Chapter-2
Understanding Computer Investigations
Prepared By,
Arun Kumar R

2.1 Preparing a Computer Investigation

* As a computer forensics professional, your role is to gather evidence from a suspect's computer to determine whether they have committed a crime or violated company policy.
* You should approach each case methodically, evaluating the evidence thoroughly and documenting the chain of evidence.
* Two examples of cases in which a computer investigation may be necessary are computer crimes and company policy violations.

2.1 Preparing a Computer Investigation (Overview of a Computer Crime)

* Computers can contain information that helps law enforcement officers determine the chain of events leading to a crime or provide evidence.
* An example of a computer crime investigation may involve a police raid of a suspected drug dealer's home, where a computer, storage media, and other electronic devices are found and collected as evidence.
* The computer forensics specialist would then examine the computer to find and organize data that could be evidence of a crime.

2.1 Preparing a Computer Investigation (Overview of a Company Policy Violation)

* Company policy violations, such as employees using company computers for personal tasks during work hours, can waste company time and resources.
* Computer forensics specialists are often used to investigate these types of policy violations.

2.2 Taking a Systematic Approach

* To properly investigate a case, you should take a systematic approach, including: assessing the case, planning your investigation, acquiring and analyzing the evidence, and completing a case report.
* You should also be aware of any risks involved in the investigation and take steps to mitigate or minimize them.

In summary, computer investigations involve the process of gathering and analyzing digital evidence to determine whether a crime or company policy violation has occurred. A systematic approach should be taken, including assessing the case, planning the investigation, acquiring and analyzing the evidence, and completing a case report. Risks should also be taken into consideration and mitigated.
